Decarboxylative fluorination of aliphatic carboxylic acids under heterogeneous delafossite AgFeO2 nanoparticle catalysis: The utilization of bimetallic cooperativity Tu V. Nguyen Vu T. Pham Tin V.T. Nguyen Nam T.S. Phan Thanh Truong ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering, HCMC University of Technology, VNU-HCM, 268 Ly Thuong Kiet, District 10, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam Department of Chemical EngineeringHCMC University of TechnologyVNU-HCM 268 Ly Thuong Kiet District 10 Ho Chi Minh City Viet Nam ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A crystalline delafossite of silver ferrite AgFeO2 nanoparticles were successfully synthesized by modified method. Physical characterizations of the AgFeO2 catalyst were obtained by several techniques including X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), X-ray Fluorescence (XRF), and nitrogen physisorption measurements. The material was applied as active heterogeneous catalyst for decarboxylative fluorination of carboxylic acids. The optimized conditions utilized the electrophilic Selectfluor reagent in acetone/H2O solvent at room temperature in 3 h. Investigation of structure/activity relationship revealed strong synergistic effect of iron on silver center. Subsequently, AgFeO2 showed remarkable higher activity than homogeneous silver salts, other metal oxides and common Ag-based heterogeneous catalysts. Leaching test indicated the exceptional stability of AgFeO2 structure as compared to other heterogeneous systems and the contribution of leached species is unlikely. Subsequently, AgFeO2 could be reused for at least 7 runs without significant degradation in activity. Keywords Silver ferrite Delafossite Fluorination Carboxylic acids Heterogeneous catalyst 1 Introduction Due to unique medicinal properties caused by carbon-fluoride bond, fluorinated compounds have been gained much attention in drug discovery [1–4]. In additional, 18F-labeled organic compounds are widely used as biological imaging agents for position emission tomography (PET) [5]. However, the presence of fluorinated substrates in nature is rare and conventional synthetic routes to introduce fluorine into organic structure often require harsh conditions and suffer from regio-selectivity issues [6–10]. Consequently, fluorine atoms are usually introduced early in the synthetic sequences which greatly increase the difficulty of accessing target molecules. Recently, modern methods based on transition-metal catalysis, therefore, have been sought as an alternative [11,12]. With regards to generation of sp2 C-F bonds, methods for the conversion of aryl metals, aryl (pseudo) halides, and activated arenes to aryl fluorides have been intensively investigated [13,14]. In contrast, the formation of C-F bonds at sp3 carbon centers remains a challenging task. In particular, mostly studies in this aspect mainly focused on the construction of α-fluoro carbonyl compounds [15–17]. Elegant works by Groves successfully described the manganese-catalyzed oxidative aliphatic C-H fluorination with fluoride ion [18]. Nevertheless, the site-specific fluorination of complex molecules, especially in late stages, is still not accessible. Notably, a novel protocol for silver-catalyzed decarboxylative fluorination of aliphatic carboxylic acids was recently disclosed [19]. Specifically, selecfluor was employed as electrophilic fluorinating reagent [20]. The reactions were conducted with excellent chemo-selectivity and functional group tolerance. Thus, the development of heterogeneous catalysts, which is preferred for industrial process especially in pharmaceutical synthesis, under mild conditions is highly demanding. The delafossite (ABO2) structure consists of close-packed double layers of edge-sharing BO6 octahedra with monovalent A+ ions (typically Cu+, Ag+, Pd+ and Pt+) positioned between the layers [21]. There were two kinds of poly-types of delafossite crystals basing on different orientation of each layer arrangement [22,23]. Applications of these materials often focus on transparent semiconducting oxides, p-type semiconductors, optoelectronic devices, transparent photodiodes, and batteries [24–28]. The utilization of delafossite in catalysis for organic transformation is still in the early stage [29–32]. In addition, silver ferrite is one of the least studied members of the delafossite family. Catalytic activities of AgFeO2 were firstly investigated in oxidation of CO [29,32]. Photocatalytic performance in degradation of methyl orange was recently introduced [33]. It is worth mentioning that catalytic behavior of AgFeO2 in modern organic transformations has not been reported. We herein present an efficient procedure for recyclable AgFeO2 catalyzed-decarboxylative fluorination of aliphatic carboxylic acids. Preliminary investigation indicated that bimetallic cooperativity of silver and iron sites in AgFeO2 is responsible for its activity. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of AgFeO2 The AgFeO2 synthetic procedure is based on the co-precipitation reaction of iron (III) hydroxide and silver oxide from Fe2(SO4)3 and AgNO3 [34]: Fe2(SO4)3 (0.5 mmol, 200 mg) and AgNO3 (1.0 mmol, 170 mg) were mixed in 40 mL deionized water. The mixture was stirred until the solute was completely dissolved. NaOH (0.4 M) was dropwise added with continuous stirring until the solution reached pH = 12. The mixture was stirred for additional 30 mins. The precipitate was separated by filtration, washed several times with deionized water and ethanol and then heated to 180 °C for 24 h. The precipitate was cooled to room temperature, separated using magnetic resonance and washed several times with deionized water, ethanol and acetone. 2.2 Catalytic studies In a typical procedure: a mixture of carboxylic acid (0.2 mmol), Selectfluor (0.5 mmol, 178 mg), 1 mL solvent (acetone/H2O = 1:1), and 1,2-dichlorobenzene (0.2 mmol, 29.4 mg) as an internal standard were added into a 8 mL reaction vial containing silver ferrite nanoparticles catalyst (20 mol %, 7.8 mg). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for indicated time. After completion, the reaction mixture was quenched with mixture of ethyl acetate (20 mL) and sodium hydroxide solution (0.4 M, 5 mL). The organic layer was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by column chromatography. The product identity was further confirmed by GC–MS, 1H NMR, and 13C NMR. To investigate the recyclability, the reaction liquid phase was removed from the reaction vessel by decantation while the external magnet held the superparamagnetic nanoparticles stationary inside the vessel. The solid material was washed with copious amounts of ethyl acetate, ethanol, water, acetone and dichloromethane, and dried 150 °C under reduced pressure in 2 h. The resulting solid was reused in further reactions under identical conditions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst synthesis and characterization The X-ray diffraction patterns of synthesized materials shows strong diffraction lines at about 2θ of 14.3°, 28.7°, 43.8° and 59.6° (see Fig. 1 ). The observed diffraction peaks showed the 0 0 l-ordered reflections consistent with preferred crystalline orientations along the c-axis. This indicated the existence of rhombohedral 3R phase [33,35]. Calculation of full width at half maximum (FWHM) values using Origin program provided estimated crystallite size of 21 nm according to Rietveld method (See Supporting Information). SEM images exhibited that a large number of silver iron oxide nanoparticles were formed with particle size is approximately 50–70 nm in diameter. Latest study by Yin and coworkers presented that size of synthesized AgFeO2 was about 50 nm [35]. Similarly, the dimensional growth of crystal observed was in good agreement with those of previous studies [36]. In TGA results, an initial weight loss of 1.4% at 100 °C was presumed due to the loss of physisorbed water and other residual solvents on the surface of the catalyst. Decomposition of remaining nitrate ion explained the loss (1.5% and 0.8%) from 200 °C to around 400 °C. At 500 °C, the decomposition of AgFeO2 was observed to release oxygen leading to the loss of about 4% in mass at 700 °C. This weight loss in the graph was similar to the number calculated by the reaction [37]. XRF results demonstrated the molar ratio between Ag/Fe approximately 1/1.04, which was similar to theoretical value. Results from isotherm confirmed the surface area of 23 m2/g (BET) which is in good agreement with literature [33,34]. 3.2 Catalytic studies Kinetic and spectroscopic studies elucidating the mechanism of silver-catalyzed decarboxylative fluorination by Flowers proposed the Ag+-OOCR (II) intermediate via oxidation Ag+ using Selectfluor oxidant via single electron transfer (SET) [38]. Decarboxylation was followed to generate alkyl radical Ṙ. Recently, our group described methods for CuFeO2-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions in which iron metal site played an important role in facilitating the oxidative SET process [39]. In addition, stabilization of alkyl radical by iron has been shown [40]. Furthermore, sp3 C-F bond formation from iron fluoride centers has been reported [41,42]. Since it is known that iron accelerated the decarboxylation [43], we reasoned that the combination of silver and iron sites in AgFeO2 could have a synergistic effect on decarboxylative fluorination. Reaction optimization was conducted for fluorination of 3,3-diphenylpropionic acid. React ratios, catalyst loading, temperature, and solvents were investigated (Table 1 ). The starting condition mimicked the reported homogeneous counterpart in using mixture of acetone/H2O solvent. In regard of electrophilic fluorine reagent, 2.5 equiv. of selectfluor provided optimal results (entries 1–3). Formation of decarboxylative hydrogenation and difluorinated products was observed when larger the amount of fluorinating reagent was used. The phenomena could be rationalized by high reactivity of alkyl radical with selectfluor and solvent [20]. Increasing or decreasing the catalyst loading from 20 mol % did not lead to higher efficiency (entries 4, 5). Specifically, no significant increase in reaction yields was detected when reactions were conducted with 25% catalyst. More amount of catalyst facilitated the rate-determining step as well as substrate inhibition [38]. Water, which was proposed to dissolve reaction components and ligate to Ag(I) under the homogeneous conditions [38], also possess remarkable impact (entries 6–8). Indeed, up to 67% yield was obtained when acetone/H2O ratio is 1:2. Poor solubility was observed when more or less water was used. Gratifyingly, reaction carried out at 0.2 M concentration produced best results with 91% of product (entry 9–12). In reported homogeneous conditions, increasing the concentration from optimized value, 0.1–0.2 M retarded reaction rate due to the stability of catalyst [38]. In contrast, we encountered difficulty in stirring reaction mixture when reaction was carried out at higher concentration than 0.2 M. The changes in reaction temperature from room temperature caused lower yields due to decomposition of selectfluor at higher temperature [44] and the poor solubility at lower temperature (entries 13–15). No detectable amount of desired product was achieved with other solvents (entry 16). The results were in good agreement with previous studies and were explained by the solvating ability with silver centers and dissolving carboxylic acids and selectfluor [38]. Reactions run at longer time did not provide remarkable changes while 85% yield was obtained in 2 h. To elucidate the role of metal sites in delafossite AgFeO2 in reaction pathway, several control experiments were performed (Table 2 ). Reactions using other silver delafossite catalysts such as AgNiO2 and AgCoO2 afforded product in only 41% and 38% yields, respectively (entries 2–3). Replacing iron with copper in delafossite composition resulted in remarkable drop in reaction efficiency (entry 4). In addition, in the absence of silver, other ferrites of copper, nickel, and cobalt showed inactivity (entries 5–7). Reactions under Ag2O and Fe2O3, which are constitutional components of AgFeO2, offered only 61% and 3% yields, respectively (entries 8, 9). Noticeably, the combination of these separated oxides gave 81% fluorinated product (entry 10). It is likely that reaction rate determining step occurred on silver metal site and iron involved in the catalytic cycle. Reactions using Ag2O mixed with other metal oxides were further demonstrated to identify partners that results in best bimetallic cooperativity with silver. Adding CuO or Cu2O into Ag2O catalyst retarded the reaction process (entries 11, 12). Though moderately higher yields were obtained when MnO2, ZnO, and TiO2 were co-utilized, the impact of iron on reaction route is still highest (entries 13–15). These indicated the existence of excellent synergistic effect of iron on silver center within delafossite structure. To highlight the exceptional activity of AgFeO2, other common nano-size silver-based heterogeneous catalytic systems were tested (Table 3 ). These solid catalysts were prepared according to reported procedures [45–48]. With respect to the influence of the oxidation state of silver, reactions under commercial nanopowder Ag(0) catalysis afforded much lower yields even in presence of Fe2O3 co-catalyst (entries 2, 3). Both Al2O3 and SiO2-supported Ag nanoparticle showed remarkable poorer activity (entries 4, 5). As expected, the reactions using Ag(II)O catalyst provided 70% yield (entry 6). This is in line with previously proposed mechanism in which formation of high oxidation state of silver was required for the product formation. Importantly, significant decrease in reaction yields was observed for reactions conducted in C2H2 environment, which is known to poison silver site [49] (entry 7). In addition, reaction using bare iron, copper, nickel, and cobalt salt catalysts showed no detectable desired product (entries 8–12). Mixing iron salt with other metal salts instead of silver did not enhance the activity of iron catalyst (entry 13). These further confirmed the necessity of silver metal site in reaction mechanism. In pharmaceutical industry, the use of heterogeneous catalyst is preferred due to the toxicity of contaminated metals and the cost of removal of them from final products [50,51]. However, lower activity is often observed under heterogeneous catalytic systems. Next, the comparison studies with kinetic behavior to evaluate the optimized conditions with reported homogeneous catalysis was demonstrated (Fig. 2 ). Particularly, reactions using AgNO3, AgOAc, and Ag(acac) salt catalysts reached only 23%, 31%, and 51% yields, respectively, at room temperature. Under optimized conditions from homogeneous report (AgNO3, 20% mol; reflux), a yield of 49% was observed. Interestingly, up to 94% yield was obtained when AgNO3 was employed in conjunction with Fe(NO3)3 even at room temperature. It is presumed that cooperativity of iron assists silver sites to overcome the common limitation of heterogeneous catalyst. To further confirm the reaction pathway, reactions in the presence of a radical scavenger were conducted. Added TEMPO (2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidinyloxyl) retarded the reaction and the formation of coupling product (R-TEMPO) between the alkyl radical and TEMPO was confirmed by GC–MS (See Supporting Information). Furthermore, an experiment using Fe2O3 catalyst failed to form desired product but generated R-TEMPO in 18% yield. Based on previous research [38,52] and the aforementioned experimental results, the tentative mechanism was proposed (Scheme 1 ). Induction period led to the formation of Ag(I)-carboxylate followed by oxidation by selectfluor to afford silver fluoride carboxylate [38]. Reports from Li and Flowers proposed the oxidation state of silver was +2 and +3, respectively [38,52]. Decarboxylation, which was known to be facile in presence of iron [40], provided alkyl radical directly from carboxylic acids or silver carboxylate. Desired product was formed either by abstracting fluorine from selectfluor or silver fluoride complex. Further investigation on trapping silver complex intermediates are required to elucidate the reaction mechanism. The stability of solid materials under tested conditions ensures catalyst recyclability. Thus, control experiments for leaching studies were performed (Fig. 3 ). Particularly, the decarboxylative fluorination was carried out under optimized conditions. The catalyst was removed from reaction mixture after first 15 min with 29% yield. Inductively coupled plasma analysis of reaction filtrate revealed the presence of Ag and Fe was <5 ppm. Expectedly, almost no further conversion was detected when reaction filtrate was stirred in longer time. It is worth mentioning that similar process was done with (Ag2O and Fe2O3) mixture and a remarkable increase in reaction yields were still observed when reaction filtrate was run in next 165 min. This could be explained by the concentration of silver (102 ppm) and iron (98 ppm) ions in the reaction filtrate. Moreover, all tested Ag(0)-base heterogeneous catalysts were vulnerable and leaching of silver species was detected (See Supporting Information). The results highlighted excellent stability of AgFeO2 and confirmed the reaction heterogeneity. With results from leaching test, recycling studies was subsequently conducted. After completion of reaction carried out under optimized condition, the liquid phase was removed from the reaction vessel by decantation. The solid material was washed with copious amounts of ethyl acetate, ethanol, water, acetone and dichloromethane, and dried at 150 °C under reduced pressure in 2 h. The material was then applied for next reactions under identical conditions as described in previous runs. The experimental results revealed that AgFeO2 could be used for at least 7 times (Fig. 4 ). Specifically, a yield of 85% of products was still achieved after the last run. Furthermore, the PXRD of reused catalyst showed similar pattern as compared to the fresh one indicating that the crystallinity was almost intact (Fig. 5 ). It is known that the presence of carboxylic acids and electrophilic fluorine source, in general, challenges the stability of heterogeneous catalysts. The generality of optimized conditions was evaluated by employing different carboxylic acids as starting materials (Table 4 ). Corresponding to 92% GC yields, a 87% isolated yield was obtained for the fluorination of 3,3-diphenylpropionic acid (entry 1). 1-Aryl acetic acid derivatives with substituents on aryl rings are active and fluorinated products were achieved in excellent yields (entries 2–5). Similarly, the conditions were also applicable for phenoxy acetic acids and decarboxylative fluorination of these compounds afforded products in good yields (entries 5–9). The reaction scope is not limited to long-chain aliphatic carboxylic acids. Reactions of 5-benzoylpentanoic acid and 3-benzoylpropionic acid provided 91% and 62% fluorinated products, respectively (entries 10, 11). Interestingly, tertiary alkyl carboxylic acid was active and 1-fluoro adamantine was obtained in moderate yield (entry 12). Also, decarboxylation of di-carboxylic acids is possible and corresponding difluorinated alkane was generated in reasonable yield (entry 13). 4 Conclusions In conclusion, delafossite AgFeO2 nanoparticles were successfully synthesized and characterized. The material was employed as efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the decarboxylative fluorination of carboxylic acids. The optimal conditions involved the use of electrophilic Selectfluor reagent in acetone/H2O solvent at room temperature in 3 h. Interestingly, preliminary investigation of metal active sites revealed the cooperative effect of iron on silver center within the delafossite structure. Subsequently, delafossite AgFeO2 exhibited significantly higher activity than silver oxides, homogeneous silver salts, and mixture of silver oxides with other first-row transition metal oxides. In addition, the delafossite structure ensured its stability while other tested Ag-based heterogeneous systems failed to maintain the heterogeneity under reaction conditions. Thus, leaching test indicated the trivial contribution of leached species and AgFeO2 could be reused for at least 7 runs without significant loss in activity. Taking advantages of bimetallic cooperativity within delafossite AgFeO2 for other organic transformations is under further investigation. Conflicts of interest There are no conflicts to declare. coredata.dc:description: A crystalline delafossite of silver ferrite AgFeO2 nanoparticles were successfully synthesized by modified method. Physical characterizations of the AgFeO2 catalyst were obtained by several techniques including X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), X-ray Fluorescence (XRF), and nitrogen physisorption measurements. The material was applied as active heterogeneous catalyst for decarboxylative fluorination of carboxylic acids. The optimized conditions utilized the electrophilic Selectfluor reagent in acetone/H2O solvent at room temperature in 3 h. Investigation of structure/activity relationship revealed strong synergistic effect of iron on silver center. Subsequently, AgFeO2 showed remarkable higher activity than homogeneous silver salts, other metal oxides and common Ag-based heterogeneous catalysts. Leaching test indicated the exceptional stability of AgFeO2 structure as compared to other heterogeneous systems and the contribution of leached species is unlikely. Subsequently, AgFeO2 could be reused for at least 7 runs without significant degradation in activity.
coredata.dc:title: Decarboxylative fluorination of aliphatic carboxylic acids under heterogeneous delafossite AgFeO2 nanoparticle catalysis: The utilization of bimetallic cooperativity
